awd_titl_txt: US-German Collaboration: Toward a quantitative understanding of navigational deficits in aging humans
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to combine computational modeling with behavioral and neuroimaging studies to characterize the mechanisms of navigational abilities in humans and understand how they decline with age. The PIs will focus on an important navigational circuit in mammals, which consists of the hippocampus and associated areas, and includes grid cells of the entorhinal cortex as well as place cells. Place cells have highly location-specific responses, turning on at one location in an environment and firing little elsewhere; grid cells by contrast fire at multiple locations within an environment, with periodically separated activity blobs in a striking triangular lattice pattern. Studies in rodents have detailed the properties of grid and place cells, and led to neural network models whose additional predictions have often been borne out by single-unit neuron recordings. However, much less is known about grid cells and place cells in humans, and the nature of interactions between different parts of the navigation circuit remains unclear, in rodents and humans. 

In this project, the PIs bring to bear virtual-reality-based behavioral experiments, ultra-high-resolution fMRI recordings during virtual navigation, and neural network modeling, to better understand the circuit for spatial navigation in humans. The PIs plan a three-pronged approach to these questions. The first is to characterize phenomenologically the characteristic errors made by humans, through navigation environments with and without accurate external landmark cues, and under other externally varying conditions, in aged and non-aged subjects. The second is to employ neural network models of grid cells, to model the network parameters that could give rise to the observed deficits, and in turn test the predictions of these models with the neuroimaging experiments. The experimental setup will permit systematic variation in the fidelity of external sensory cues, to probe the relative contributions of the complementary computations of dead-reckoning (path integration) versus landmark-based navigation, and uncover their potential neural substrates in humans. The results will help to develop models of how parallel streams of spatial information are combined and processed across brain areas to aid in navigation. The third component is to develop accurate algorithms for extracting spatial information from high-resolution fMRI data from regions and sub-regions of the entorhinal-hippocampal complex. The aim is to map the distribution of location information across areas and learn where it is most compromised in old age.

This award is being co-funded by NSF's Office of the Director, International Science and Engineering.  A companion project is being funded by the German Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF).

por.por_cntn:
This award allowed us to study the brain's circuits for navigation in humans and animals. Specifically, we considered two key problems: 1) How to find and quantify the sources of error during a navigational behavior, and what are the differences in these sources of error between healthy and aged human subjects? 2) Building models about how the brain might solve the challenging navigation problem known as SLAM, or simultaneous localization and mapping.

 

On the first problem, we proposed a novel temporally-resolved technique to examine the sources of accumulating error in a navigation task. The parameters of the error-accumulation equation could be fit on a per-subject basis across the varied paths, and revealed whether the errors could be ascribed to limited memory in the underlying process of estimating position by adding up past displacements; or random errors in the estimation of one’s movement speed; or systematic under- or overestimation of the size of one’s displacements; or errors in reporting, at the end of the path, one’s internal estimate of position. We helped to design experimental behavioral experiments, carried out by co-PI Wolbers’ group, and analyzed performance in young and ageing human subjects. In young humans, we found that the main source of error across subjects is random (unbiased) noise in movement velocity estimation, while all systemic biases are minimal, showing that the underlying neural system is tuned to eliminate leaks and biases and might only be limited by sensory noise, a finding that generalizes to cognitive areas what has previously been believed to be true for the sensory periphery. In aging subjects, we found that the unbiased velocity estimation noise grew, but notably other potential sources of error remained small – in other words, the weakest link in young adults got weaker with aging, but other errors remained small. Our analysis method could be used in drug discovery and screens, because precise quantification of error sources and changes in performance after dosing will enable sensitive assaying of the efficacy of the potential drug.

 

On the second problem, our interest was to reach beyond models that describe simple spatial computations, and instead ask how the brain might enable animals to solve the SLAM problem. To localize accurately within a space with noisy velocity sensing requires that one’s estimates are occasionally reset by landmarks. However, landmarks are only informative if their spatial locations are known; for this to be the case, landmarks have to be assigned spatial coordinates, and if there are multiple similar-looking landmarks, that ambiguity must be resolved before knowing which coordinate to use in resetting one’s position estimate. Simultaneously resolving the ambiguity about location for oneself and for landmarks in novel environments or ambiguous landmarks in familiar environments, is the computationally complex SLAM problem. We conceived a series of featureless random polygon environments in which the only landmarks are the walls, which locally look the same within and across environments. We trained recurrent neural networks to solve such hard tasks, in search of possible neural solutions. Using noisy motion data and highly limited landmark data from bumping into walls and no long-range vision, the agent has to both determine which environment it is in out of many possible ones (“mapping”), and localize within the environment. Achieving high accuracy on this task requires high-dimensional probabilistic estimation. We show that our trained networks can solve these problems and generalize to new environments. Some of the neural responses we found in the trained networks resemble some less-well understood features of hippocampal place cells, and thus shed light on what computations these cells might perform. We believe our results constitute the first fully neural models of how the brain might solve the SLAM problem in navigation. By further studying how our models solve the task, we will be able to generate predictions and shed new light on the computations performed by the brain's navigational circuit.
